title.value: Estimating individual minimum calibration for deep-learning with predictive performance recovery: An example case of gait surface classification from wearable sensor gait data
title.justification: The title is clearly stated at the beginning of the paper, providing the main focus of the research.
title.quote: Estimating individual minimum calibration for deep-learning with predictive performance recovery: An example case of gait surface classification from wearable sensor gait data

extractions.description: This study investigates the amount of calibration training data needed to achieve strong model performance in deep-learning classification of gait surfaces from wearable sensor data, using a subject-wise training method.

type.justification: The study involves the use of a database from actual trials to develop and assess the performance of deep-learning classifiers, indicating practical experimentation.
type.quote: A database of 30 young, healthy adults performing multiple walking trials across nine different surfaces while fit with inertial measurement unit sensors on the lower limbs was used to develop a deep-learning classifier.

name.justification: The application of deep learning in this paper is focused on biomechanical data, particularly gait surface classification, which falls under biomechanics.
The research applies machine learning techniques for classification tasks, which is a subfield used in the study.
name.quote: Machine learning Random/Record-wise split Subject-wise split

name.justification: The paper discusses dealing with clinical datasets and data splitting, associating it as an application domain related to healthcare data.
name.quote: Clinical datasets often comprise multiple data points or trials sampled from a single participant.

name.value: Deep-learning classifier for gait surface classification
name.justification: The paper discusses developing a deep-learning classifier specifically for the classification of gait surfaces from sensor data.
name.quote: A database of 30 young, healthy adults performing multiple walking trials across nine different surfaces while fit with inertial measurement unit sensors on the lower limbs was used to develop a deep-learning classifier.

is_contributed.justification: The paper describes the development of this model within the study scope, indicating it is an original contribution.
is_contributed.quote: ...was used to develop a deep-learning classifier.

is_executed.justification: The model is executed as it is applied to classify gait data and to analyze the impact of calibration size on model performance.
is_executed.quote: ...was used to develop a deep-learning classifier.

is_compared.justification: The primary focus is on assessing calibration size effects, with less emphasis on comparing this model against others.
is_compared.quote: This study aims to investigate the relationship between calibration training set size and prediction accuracy on the calibration test set.
